details.title: Electromigration reliability issues in dual-damascene Cu interconnections

authors.affiliation: Texas Instrum. Inc., Dallas, TX, USA

p: Ennis T. Ogawa was a research associate at The University of Texas at Austin at the Microelectronics Research Center's Interconnect and Packaging Laboratory. He is now with Texas Instruments, Inc. He is working in the Materials Reliability R&D Group under Silicon Technology Development at Texas Instruments, Inc. in Dallas. He received his B.S. in 1986 in physics from Stanford University, and his Ph.D. in 1994 in physics at The University of Texas at Austin in the field of high-temperature superconductivity. Then he worked as a postdoctoral fellow in the Interconnect and Packaging Laboratory at The University of Texas at Austin and remained as a Research Associate until mid-2001. During this period, he learned much from a targeted emphasis on technology-directed materials research under the guidance of Professor P. S. Ho. Dr. Ogawa's research interests there focused on the thermal conduction of low-$k$ polymers, metal-polymer adhesion, low-$k$ materials characterization, interconnect thermal stress, and Al(Cu)-based and Cu-based electromigration. His current interests address issues pertaining to the reliability of Cu/low-$k$ backend Si technology such as electromigration, stress-induced voiding, intermetal and interlevel dielectric reliability, and thermal management.

authors.name: E.T. Ogawa

p: Ki-Don Lee is a Ph.D. student of The University of Texas at Austin. He received his M.S. in 2000 in materials science and engineering from The University of Texas at Austin, and his B.S. in 1997 in materials engineering from SungKyunKwan University, Korea. He is working on electromigration induced failure analysis and statistical modeling of Cu/low $k$ dual-damascene interconnects.

Volker A. Blaschke is the senior assignee for Conexant Systems, Inc. at International Sematech in Austin. He is the team leader for the interconnect reliability activities and is chairperson of the reliability working group whose charter is to mentor and align reliability activities with the Sematech member companies. Volker holds a Dipl. Ing. (F.H.) in micromechanics from University of Applied Sciences in Munich, and M.S. in electrical and computer engineering from University of Texas at Austin. He has over 10 years experience in the semiconductor industry in process development, integration and early product startup.
Paul S. Ho is a Professor at The University of Texas at Austin and is director of Interconnect and Packaging Laboratory at the Microelectronics Research Center, Austin, TX.

details.abstract: Electromigration studies on Cu interconnects are reviewed. Some history and more recent results are discussed along with a description of the present interpretations of the active mass transport mechanisms involved in Cu electromigration. The issue of the dual-damascene process and its potential effect on EM reliability is described with special focus on the peculiarities of the dual-damascene interconnect architecture compared to more conventional subtractively etched Al-based interconnects. Experiments performed on dual-damascene interconnects that highlight electromigration reliability issues such as early failure, a tentative explanation for via electromigration failure, and the Blech effect, are summarized. Emphasis is placed on an experimental methodology that uses large interconnect ensembles in a multi-link configuration. Such a large scale study of nearly 10000 interconnects has shown statistical evidence of bimodal failure behavior consistent with the presence of a weak and strong failure mode, which have been identified as voiding, respectively, within the via and the trench at the cathode end of an interconnect. A multi-link approach has also demonstrated a length-dependent distribution of failures that yields a (j/spl middot/L)/sub c/ product value of about 9000 A/cm in dual-damascene Cu/oxide interconnections and is consistent with mass transport that is controlled by the presence of extended defects within Cu such as grain boundaries, interfaces, and/or surfaces. The study of dual-damascene Cu has demonstrated the importance of statistics in analyzing EM reliability.

references.title: Electromigration and stress-induced voiding in fine Al and Al-alloy thin-film lines

context.text: Although some aspects of this rich past are discussed, the history is covered in great detail by [1], [3]–[4][5].

Generally, in polygranular Al-based interconnects, GB diffusion is thought to be the controlling mechanism, but as line widths are decreased or as the grains within the interconnect approach a bamboo structure, then interface diffusion is more important [4], [115] [116]–
[118].

As a consequence, the explicit flux divergence for Al-based EM is located over the top of the cathode end (electron source) W-via, and EM voiding is often located there in submicron interconnects with bamboo-type grains [4], [28], [35], [36], [120], [121].
Hence, in unpassivated and heat-treated Al lines, the threshold product appears to range between 500 and 1260 A/cm at 350 °C [4], [25], [167].

In a passivated Al interconnect, the threshold value appears to be in the range of 2500 to 4500 A/cm [4], [137], [150], [168], [169], and within a given temperature range, passivated Al appears to show little temperature dependence [137], [138].

The value of 9000 A/cm is 2 to 3 times as high as the value observed in comparable oxide passivated Al(Cu) interconnects [4], [137], [150], [168], [169] and is also similarly larger than recently obtained results in SD Cu interconnects [156], [158], [191], [192].

links.abstract: Interconnections will become the limit in performance and reliability at submicrometer dimensions. Long-distance interconnections are defined using models based on resistivity, and it is found that more than half of the interconnections will become categorized as such at 0.5-µm feature sizes. The resistivity of even less resistive materials, therefore, will become important. A model for analyzing the trends of material usage for interconnections and for projecting design rules is presented....

Another type of structure is a “drift” or “Blech” structure [25]–
[27], where the interconnect is deposited directly over a thin redundant layer of higher resistivity material such as “Al over titanium nitride” or “Cu over tungsten”.
A good example might be the observation of a critical-length effect, first seen in unpassivated and oxide-passivated Al interconnects [25], [33], [137], [138].
The short-length or Blech effect was first elucidated by the pioneering studies in the mid-1970s [25], [27], [162].
Hence, in unpassivated and heat-treated Al lines, the threshold product appears to range between 500 and 1260 A/cm at 350 °C [4], [25], [167].

The threshold behavior in unpassivated Al is also temperature dependent—decreasing with increasing temperature—and is attributed to changes in the thermo-mechanical properties of a given interconnect system [25].

references.title: Electromigration threshold in damascene versus plasma-etched interconnects

context.text: The metal is filled-in afterwards with some conformal deposition technology, usually ECD or CVD. (This has been very successfully done for Al-based damascene technology [33]–[36].) The interconnect structure is formed when the excess metal is removed by CMP.
A good example might be the observation of a critical-length effect, first seen in unpassivated and oxide-passivated Al interconnects [25], [33], [137], [138].

The threshold product has remained over the years an important parameter for EM studies, not just because of its fundamental importance [33], [170]–[181], but also because of its potential practical applications.
Threshold studies of damascene interconnects are rarer still [33], [156], [158], [191], [192].

A comparison between unpassivated Al plasma-etched and damascene interconnects [33] indicated that damascene interconnects show a higher threshold product (1770 compared to 1020 A/cm in the range 170–200 °C) and is presumably a result of the greater amount of surrounding passivation in a damascene interconnect.

links.abstract: The electromigration properties of electroless plated copper films have been evaluated under DC stress conditions. The formation of microvoids and the diffusion of copper through the seed layer caused an increase of the line resistance in the initial stage of the stressing. The current density dependence and the activation energy of the lifetime were determined.

context.text: EM studies on Cu alloy-films and interconnects determined that doping effects are potentially strong, with Zr and Sn causing drastic reductions in EM rate [49] [50]–[54][59].
Studies on the short-length effect in Cu interconnects is not as comprehensive yet but is growing rapidly [54], [156], [158], [189]–[192].

The early work on unpassivated Cu using drift-type structures similar to those used originally by Blech showed that the threshold product was about 525 A/cm (300 °C) [54] to 900–1600 A/cm (175–225 °C) [189].
The constancy of the threshold product would be anticipated because the product term, \$Z^{\ast}_{\rm eff}\cdot \rho\cdot j\$ should be relatively independent of temperature [54].

If one uses the values in [54] to estimate the value of \$Z^{\ast}_{\rm eff}\$, then a threshold product of 9000 A/cm would correspond to a \$Z^{\ast}_{\rm eff}\$, of about −0.4:

•\$\Omega = 11.8\cdot 10^{-24}\$ cm3,
•\$\Delta\sigma = 2.6\cdot 10^9\$ dyne/cm2,
•\$e = 1.602\cdot 10^{-19}\$ C,
•\$\rho_{\rm Cu}(T = 350\$ °C) \$= 5.66\cdot 10^{-6}\, \Omega\cdot\$ cm.

These numbers are remarkably consistent with the \$Z^{\ast}_{\rm eff}= {-}0.7\$ value determined in unpassivated Cu [189], although [54] and [196] showed \$Z^{\ast}_{\rm eff}\$ to be about −6.4 and −4.8, respectively.

context.text: Usually, a discussion of the various pathways to cause EM-related voiding can be based on the drift equation [67], [68]: .

A more detailed EM study that focused on determining some measure of the relative rates of mass transport has identified that surface migration is most likely the fastest diffusive pathway, outpacing both GB [68], [90]–[92] and interface diffusion [93].
The EM drift velocity and AE results from [68], [90] point strongly to a fast surface diffusion pathway, especially in the submicron regime.

On the other hand, a very fast passivation interface pathway that greatly surpasses mass depletion at the via bottom [68], [91] could transport enough material to enable steady-state back-stress development to counteract EM-induced line or via failure.
Because EM is a diffusion-controlled mass transport process, the AE (\$Q_{\rm eff}\$) strongly depends on the diffusion path in which the metal atoms move [67]–[68][69].
The determined weak-mode AE (≈1.0 eV) is higher than that estimated for trench-level voiding (≈0.8 to 0.9 eV) [68].
Also, results on PVD Cu lines have estimated \${-}0.1 \leq Z^{\ast}_{\rm eff}\leq -0.8\$ [68].

links.abstract: Reflow-sputtered Al-0.5wt%Cu/Nb-liner dual damascene interconnects with low-k organic spin-on glass (SOG) passivation were fabricated for the first time. A significant improvement in median time-to-failure (MTF) for electromigration (EM) was observed when the SOG was compared to a standard TEOS passivation. This improvement is due to the low Young's modulus of the SOG, which suppresses stress evolution in the Al interconnects near the via during EM testing.

references.text: T. Usui, "Significant improvement in electromigration of reflow-sputtered Al-0.5%stCu/Nb-liner dual damascene interconnects with low-k organic SOG dielectric", 38th Annu. IEEE Int. Reliability Phys. Symp. Proc., pp. 221-226, 2000.

references.title: Electromigration early failure distribution in submicron interconnects

context.text: Previous work [126], [127] shows that the reliability of Al-based interconnects does not show important deviation from mono-modal behavior down to nearly 1 part in \$10^5\$ interconnects.
References [126], [127], [150] have been most explicit in characterizing the possible role of early or extrinsic failure on a very large scale in Al(Cu) technology.

If the extrinsic population is present in less than \$10^9\$ interconnects, for example, standard EM testing would be unable to detect their influence in the collection of real-world devices operating in the field while having an inordinately large influence on device reliability. (In reality, the picture is more complicated by the differing interconnect lengths and widths present within a working microelectronics device.) A promising approach in [126], [127], [150], is to focus on so-called weak-link structures.

links.abstract: The early failure issue in electromigration (EM) has been an unresolved subject of study over the last several decades. A satisfying experimental approach for the detection and analysis of early failures has not yet been established. In this study, a new technique utilizing large interconnect arrays in conjunction with the well-known Wheatstone bridge is presented. A total of more than 20,000 interconnects were tested. The results indicate that the EM failure mechanism studied here follows log-n...

In a passivated Al interconnect, the threshold value appears to be in the range of 2500 to 4500 A/cm [4], [137], [150], [168], [169], and within a given temperature range, passivated Al appears to show little temperature dependence [137], [138].

The value of 9000 A/cm is 2 to 3 times as high as the value observed in comparable oxide passivated Al(Cu) interconnects [4], [137], [150], [168], [169] and is also similarly larger than recently obtained results in SD Cu interconnects [156], [158], [191], [192].

links.abstract: The correct model for the electromigration failure distribution is a key issue in reliability methodology. Usually, the failure times of a sample are fitted by a single log-normal distribution. However, in some cases relevant deviations can be found. In this paper two types of non-log-normal distributions observed on via-line structures are discussed. They can be modeled by two types of bimodal distributions, each composed of two log-normal distributions. Both models consider different failure m...

context.text: References [126], [127], [150] have been most explicit in characterizing the possible role of early or extrinsic failure on a very large scale in Al(Cu) technology.

If the extrinsic population is present in less than \$10^9\$ interconnects, for example, standard EM testing would be unable to detect their influence in the collection of real-world devices operating in the field while having an inordinately large influence on device reliability. (In reality, the picture is more complicated by the differing interconnect lengths and widths present within a working microelectronics device.) A promising approach in [126], [127], [150], is to focus on so-called weak-link structures.

In a passivated Al interconnect, the threshold value appears to be in the range of 2500 to 4500 A/cm [4], [137], [150], [168], [169], and within a given temperature range, passivated Al appears to show little temperature dependence [137], [138].

The value of 9000 A/cm is 2 to 3 times as high as the value observed in comparable oxide passivated Al(Cu) interconnects [4], [137], [150], [168], [169] and is also similarly larger than recently obtained results in SD Cu interconnects [156], [158], [191], [192].

links.abstract: A simple one-dimensional continuum model for electromigration transport has been fairly successful as a tool for understanding many empirical observations of electromigration phenomena in encapsulated interconnect lines on integrated circuits. It also causes a significant difference in the short-length resistance saturation for the two current directions.

An electromigration resistant power grid may be designed which takes advantage of the short-length effect.

context.text: Studies on the short-length effect in Cu interconnects is not as comprehensive yet but is growing rapidly [54], [156], [158], [189]–[192].

The early work on unpassivated Cu using drift-type structures similar to those used originally by Blech showed that the threshold product was about 525 A/cm (300 °C) [54] to 900–1600 A/cm (175–225 °C) [189].

Reference [189] noted that a comparison between unpassivated Al-based and Cu-based interconnects on the same type of test structure showed that the threshold product in Cu was as much as 1.8 times higher than Al.

A temperature-dependent study of the threshold product in unpassivated Cu showed a decrease in the threshold product from about 1200 A/cm to about 400 A/cm in the temperature range 200–280 °C [189]; this was attributed the transition at 200 °C to a change in the dominant deformation mechanism at that temperature.

These numbers are remarkably consistent with the \$Z^{\ast}_{\rm eff}= {-}0.7\$ value determined in unpassivated Cu [189], although [54] and [196] showed \$Z^{\ast}_{\rm eff}\$ to be about −6.4 and −4.8, respectively.

context.text: Studies on the short-length effect in Cu interconnects is not as comprehensive yet but is growing rapidly [54], [156], [158], [189]–[191][192].
Threshold studies of damascene interconnects are rarer still [33], [156], [158], [191], [192].

Recent studies on passivated SD Cu indicate that the threshold product lies in the range of 2800 to 3500 A/cm [156], [191] at 300 °C and/or decreases from 3940 down to 2660 A/cm as temperature is decreased from 400 to 295 °C [158], [192].

The value of 9000 A/cm is 2 to 3 times as high as the value observed in comparable oxide passivated Al(Cu) interconnects [4], [137], [150], [168], [169] and is also similarly larger than recently obtained results in SD Cu interconnects [156], [158], [191], [192].

context.text: More recent results examining the temperature dependence of the Blech effect in nitride-passivated DD Cu/oxide multi-link \$(j\cdot L)_c\$ structures from a more mature process indicate that \$(j\cdot L)_c \approx 3700\$ A/cm between 340 and 400 °C; however, in this case, no distinct temperature dependence of the threshold product was observed [195].
